result.execSummary:
The defendant Joanit Enrique Ortiz was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possession of THC (2nd+ Offense), a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(e).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes:
Court costs and victim/witness surcharges are to be paid by 5/20/2016; nonpayment penalty shall be a civil judgment.
Defendant is to provide a DNA sample and pay related surcharge by 5/20/2016; nonpayment penalty shall be a civil judgment.
Court advised the defendant that as a convicted felon he may no longer use or possess any firearms; also he may not vote in any election until his civil rights have been restored.

No violations of State or Federal law that rise to the level of probable cause.
No alcohol or controlled substances.

Successfully complete a Cognitive Thinking Behavioral Modification course.
No drivers license suspension.

AODA assessment and any recommended treatment.
Absolute sobriety with random urine screens.

records.addlTxt:
Defendant Joanit Enrique Ortiz in court with attorney Darryl E. Smith.  Nicholas Steven Cerwin appeared for the State of Wisconsin./ SAB
  Defendant  advised that if he is not a US citizen deportation is possible.   Defendant changes plea to GUILTY. Defendant examined as to his plea, advised of his Constitutional rights and the maximum penalty. Court found that defendant freely, voluntarily and intelligently waived his rights. Plea questionnaire received and filed. Parties stipulate to the complaint as a factual basis to sustain defendant's plea. Court found defendant guilty as charged in the information and ordered a Judgment of Conviction be entered on the record. 
  Sentencing proceeded.  Statements by the State, defense and defendant.  
The Court sentenced the defendant to serve 90 days in the House of Correction, consecutive to any other sentence, credit for 1 day, Huber privileges for work and AODA treatment. IMPOSED and STAYED. The Court placed the defendant on PROBATION for a period of 1 YEAR.   
CONDITIONS OF PROBATION:
-No violations of State or Federal law that rise to the level of probable cause
-AODA assessment and any recommended treatment
-Absolute sobriety with random urine screens
-No alcohol or controlled substances
-Work or school
-Successfully complete a Cognitive Thinking Behavioral Modification course
-No drivers license suspension
-Court costs and victim/witness surcharges are to be paid by 5/20/2016; nonpayment penalty shall be a civil judgment
-Defendant is to provide a DNA sample and pay related surcharge by 5/20/2016; nonpayment penalty shall be a civil judgment
Court advised the defendant that as a convicted felon he may no longer use or possess any firearms; also he may not vote in any election until his civil rights have been restored.
Filed, Ineligible Voting Notice and Acknowledgement
Filed, Notice of Right to Seek Postconviction Relief
